Bitcoin ETFs ขยายการขาดทุนด้วยการถอนเงินออก 545 ล้านดอลลาร์ ขณะที่ BTC ใกล้ 70K ดอลลาร์

Bitcoin ETFs extend losses with $545M outflows as BTC nears $70K

1d ago//Cointelegraph by Helen Partz
bitcoinregulation
AI

Summary

TH

Spot Bitcoin ETFs ขยายการขาดทุนด้วยการถอนเงินออก (outflows) 545 ล้านดอลลาร์ ส่งผลให้กระแสเงินรายสัปดาห์และรายปีกลับเป็นลบ ขณะที่ราคา Bitcoin อยู่ใกล้ระดับ 70,000 ดอลลาร์ แม้จะมีการถอนเงินออกจำนวนมาก แต่นักวิเคราะห์ชี้ให้เห็นถึงความยืดหยุ่นของนักลงทุน โดยประเมินว่าสินทรัพย์เพียง 6% เท่านั้นที่ออกจากกองทุน ซึ่งบ่งชี้ว่าส่วนใหญ่ยังคง HODL ถือครองสินทรัพย์ผ่านความผันผวน แม้ว่ามูลค่าตลาดคริปโตโดยรวมจะลดลง 20% จากต้นปีก็ตาม ในขณะเดียวกัน กองทุน altcoin ก็มีการเคลื่อนไหวผสมผสานกัน โดย Ether (ETH) ETFs มีการถอนเงินออก 79.5 ล้านดอลลาร์ ในขณะที่ XRP funds มีกระแสเข้าเล็กน้อย 4.8 ล้านดอลลาร์ และ Solana (SOL) ETFs มีการถอนเงินออก 6.7 ล้านดอลลาร์

EN

Spot Bitcoin ETFs experienced significant outflows of $545 million, pushing weekly and year-to-date flows into negative territory as Bitcoin prices hover near $70,000. Despite the redemptions, which total a net deficit of $1.8 billion for the year, analysts highlight investor resilience, noting that only about 6% of total assets have exited the funds. This suggests that most investors are HODLing through the volatility, even as the total crypto market capitalization has dropped by approximately 20% since the start of the year.

Key Points

  • Spot Bitcoin ETFs recorded $545 million in outflows, resulting in a year-to-date net deficit of $1.8 billion.
  • Analysts note investor resilience, stating that only 6% of total assets have exited despite price drops.
  • Ether (ETH) ETFs faced outflows of $79.5 million, while XRP funds saw modest inflows.

Article

Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) extended losses on Wednesday amid BTC price approaching the $70,000 mark, adding to mounting pressure across digital asset markets. According to data from SoSoValue, spot Bitcoin ( BTC ) ETFs recorded $545 million in outflows on the day, pushing weekly flows into the negative with $255 million in net outflows. Year-to-date, the funds have attracted $3.5 billion in inflows but seen $5.4 billion in redemptions, leaving them net negative by $1.8 billion. Total assets under management stand at $93.5 billion. Spot Bitcoin ETF flows since Jan. 26, 2026. Source: SoSoValue The bearish ETF sentiment mirrors broader market weakness, with total cryptocurrency market capitalization down around 20% year-to-date, falling from about $3 trillion to $2.5 trillion at the time of publication, according to CoinGecko. Bitcoin ETF investors HODL, with only 6% of assets exiting the market Despite facing their biggest losses since launching two years ago , some analysts say Bitcoin ETFs are resilient amid the market volatility . With cumulative net inflows for spot Bitcoin ETFs measured at $54.8 billion, the market is just 13% down from its peak of $62.9 billion in October last year. “That's not too shabby considering these funds took in around $63 billion at their peak,” Bloomberg ETF analyst James Seyffart said in an X post on Wednesday. Eric Balchunas, senior ETF analyst at Bloomberg, said the majority of Bitcoin ETF investors have held onto their positions despite the recent downturn. Source: Eric Balchunas Balchunas estimated that only around 6% of total assets have exited the funds, even as Bitcoin prices have fallen sharply and many investors remain underwater. He also mentioned that BlackRock’s iShares Bitcoin ETF (IBIT) saw its assets drop to $60 billion after peaking at $100 billion “for a hot second.” Related: Bitcoin ETFs bounce $562M after $1.5B sell-off, as headwinds linger “It could stay stuck at this level for the next three years and it would still be the all time fastest ETF to hit [$]60 billion,” he added. Against the backdrop of heavy outflows from Bitcoin ETFs, altcoin funds also saw mixed flows. Ether ( ETH ) ETFs recorded $79.5 million in outflows on Wednesday, while XRP ( XRP ) funds posted modest inflows of $4.8 million. Solana ( SOL ) ETFs, meanwhile, saw outflows of $6.7 million. Magazine: Bitcoin’s ‘miner exodus,’ UK bans some Coinbase crypto ads: Hodler’s Digest, Jan. 25 – 31 Cointelegraph is committed to independent, transparent journalism.
